JavaScript.q: What are the different data types in JavaScript?
JavaScript.a: String, Number, Boolean, Null, Undefined, Symbol, BigInt.
A closure is a function that has access to its own scope, the outer function's scope, and the global scope.
It handles asynchronous tasks by processing the call stack and the callback queue in JavaScript.

JavaScript.q: Difference between var, let, and const?
JavaScript.a: var is function scoped, let and const are block scoped; const cannot be reassigned.
Hoisting is JavaScript's behavior of moving declarations to the top of the current scope before execution.
Arrow functions provide a shorter syntax and do not bind their own 'this'.
'this' refers to the object that is executing the current function.
Promises represent the eventual completion (or failure) of an asynchronous operation.
Syntax for handling asynchronous operations more easily, based on promises.
Every object has a prototype object from which it can inherit properties and methods.
== compares values with type coercion, === compares values strictly without coercion.
Not-a-Number, represents an invalid number operation.
typeof NaN returns 'number'.
Strings enclosed in backticks (`) that allow interpolation using ${expression}.
Extracting values from arrays or objects into variables.
for..in iterates over keys, for..of iterates over values.
Attaching a single event listener on a parent element to handle events on children.
Immediately Invoked Function Expression - a function executed immediately after definition.
A way to opt into a restricted variant of JavaScript, catching common coding mistakes.
Functions that take other functions as arguments or return functions.

JavaScript.q: What is the difference between shallow copy and deep copy?
JavaScript.a: Shallow copy copies top-level objects, deep copy duplicates nested objects as well.
Array methods to transform, filter, or reduce array data.
JavaScript Object Notation, a lightweight data interchange format.

JavaScript.q: What is the difference between null and undefined?
JavaScript.a: null = intentional absence of value, undefined = variable declared but not assigned.
A function passed as an argument to another function to be executed later.
Function declarations are hoisted to the top of their scope, allowing calls before declaration.

JavaScript.q: What is the difference between function declaration and expression?
JavaScript.a: Declaration is hoisted, expression is not.
Files or pieces of code that can export and import functionality.
Unique and immutable primitive values used as object property keys.
A numeric type that can represent integers larger than Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER.
Functions that can be paused and resumed using the yield keyword.

JavaScript.q: Difference between synchronous and asynchronous code?
JavaScript.a: Synchronous executes line by line; asynchronous runs operations in background.
Queue for promises and mutation observers, executed before macrotasks.
setTimeout executes once after delay, setInterval repeats at intervals.
Browser storage persisting data even after page reload.
Browser storage persisting data until tab is closed.

JavaScript.q: Difference between call, apply, and bind?
JavaScript.a: call: invoke function with args, apply: invoke with array, bind: returns new function.
Events propagate from child elements up to parent elements.
Events propagate from parent elements down to child elements before bubbling.
Delays execution of a function until after a certain wait time has passed.
Ensures a function is called at most once every specified interval.
const prevents reassignment of variable, freeze prevents modification of object properties.
Convert objects to JSON string and parse JSON string to object.

JavaScript.q: Difference between synchronous loop and asynchronous loop?
JavaScript.a: Synchronous loop blocks execution, asynchronous loop does not.
Sequential execution of multiple promises using then() methods.
Iterator that can be used with for-await-of loop to handle async data streams.
Collection of key-value pairs with weakly held keys (garbage collected if no reference).
Collection of objects held weakly, automatically removed when no references exist.
Design pattern used to encapsulate private and public methods in JS.
ES6 introduces let/const, arrow functions, classes, promises, template literals, modules.
Optimization technique where last function call in a function can reuse current stack frame.
Transforming a function with multiple arguments into a sequence of functions each taking one argument.
Optimization technique to cache results of expensive function calls.

JavaScript.q: What is strict equality in JavaScript?
JavaScript.a: Comparison using === operator without type conversion.

TypeScript.a: TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that adds static typing and compile-time checking.
TypeScript.ex: let name: string = 'Prasad';

TypeScript.a: For early error detection, better tooling, and type safety.
TypeScript.ex: function add(a: number, b: number): number { return a + b; }

TypeScript.q: How is TypeScript different from JavaScript?
TypeScript.a: TypeScript adds types, interfaces, and compile-time checks to JavaScript.
TypeScript.ex: let age: number = 25; // error if assigned a string

TypeScript.q: What are data types in TypeScript?
TypeScript.a: string, number, boolean, null, undefined, any, unknown, never, void, array, tuple, enum.
TypeScript.ex: let arr: number[] = [1, 2, 3];

TypeScript.a: It defines the structure of an object.
TypeScript.ex: interface User { name: string; age: number; }

TypeScript.a: Enums define a set of named constants.
TypeScript.ex: enum Direction { Up, Down, Left, Right }

TypeScript.a: Custom names for types or unions.
TypeScript.ex: type ID = string | number;

TypeScript.a: Disables type checking for that variable.
TypeScript.ex: let value: any = 10; value = 'hello';

TypeScript.a: Similar to any but safer; must check before using.
TypeScript.ex: let data: unknown = 'hi'; if (typeof data === 'string') console.log(data.toUpperCase());

TypeScript.a: Represents values that never occur.
TypeScript.ex: function fail(): never { throw new Error('Error'); }

TypeScript.a: Compiler automatically detects types.
TypeScript.ex: let count = 5; // inferred as number

TypeScript.a: Used to create reusable components that work with different types.
TypeScript.ex: function identity<T>(val: T): T { return val; }

TypeScript.a: An array with fixed types and order.
TypeScript.ex: let person: [string, number] = ['Prasad', 25];

TypeScript.a: Allow multiple possible types.
TypeScript.ex: let id: string | number = 101;

TypeScript.a: Combines multiple types.
TypeScript.ex: type A = { a: string }; type B = { b: number }; type C = A & B;

TypeScript.a: Manually telling compiler a variable’s type.
TypeScript.ex: let val: unknown = 'hi'; let len = (val as string).length;

TypeScript.a: Used to organize code using import/export.
TypeScript.ex: export function greet() { console.log('Hi'); }

TypeScript.a: Type compatibility depends on structure, not name.
TypeScript.ex: type Point = { x: number }; let p: Point = { x: 10 };

TypeScript.a: Functions that modify classes or properties.
TypeScript.ex: function Logger(target: any) { console.log('Class created:', target); }

TypeScript.a: Prevents modification after initialization.
TypeScript.ex: interface User { readonly id: number; name: string; }

TypeScript.a: Built-in types like Partial, Pick, Omit, Readonly.
TypeScript.ex: type PartialUser = Partial<{ name: string; age: number; }>

TypeScript.a: Extracts property names as union type.
TypeScript.ex: type Person = { name: string; age: number }; type Keys = keyof Person; // 'name' | 'age'

TypeScript.a: Gets the type of a variable or object.
TypeScript.ex: let num = 10; type NumType = typeof num;

TypeScript.a: Transforms one type into another.
TypeScript.ex: type Readonly<T> = { readonly [K in keyof T]: T[K] };

TypeScript.a: Applies conditions to types.
TypeScript.ex: type IsString<T> = T extends string ? true : false;

TypeScript.a: Used in conditional types to infer types automatically.
TypeScript.ex: type ReturnType<T> = T extends (...args: any[]) => infer R ? R : any;

TypeScript.a: Refining types using runtime checks.
TypeScript.ex: function print(val: string | number) { if (typeof val === 'string') console.log(val.toUpperCase()); }

TypeScript.a: Used for functions that return nothing.
TypeScript.ex: function logMessage(): void { console.log('Hello'); }

TypeScript.a: Represents non-primitive values.
TypeScript.ex: let obj: object = { name: 'TS' };

TypeScript.a: Enables all strict type checking options.
TypeScript.ex: Inside tsconfig.json: { 'compilerOptions': { 'strict': true } }

TypeScript.a: Configuration file for TypeScript compiler settings.
TypeScript.ex: { 'compilerOptions': { 'target': 'es6' } }

TypeScript.a: Using 'tsc' command to generate JS files.
TypeScript.ex: tsc app.ts

TypeScript.a: Define types for dynamic object keys.
TypeScript.ex: interface Dictionary { [key: string]: string; }

TypeScript.a: Use '?' symbol in interface properties.
TypeScript.ex: interface User { name: string; age?: number; }

TypeScript.a: A class that can’t be instantiated and may contain abstract methods.
TypeScript.ex: abstract class Animal { abstract sound(): void; }

TypeScript.a: Used to describe external code with 'declare'.
TypeScript.ex: declare let process: any;

TypeScript.a: Adding new members to existing modules.
TypeScript.ex: declare module 'fs' { export function customFunc(): void; }

TypeScript.a: Used for React components written in .tsx files.
TypeScript.ex:
const App = () =>

Hello TSX

;

TypeScript.a: Used to group related code under one name.
TypeScript.ex: namespace Utils { export const PI = 3.14; }

TypeScript.a: Combining multiple declarations with the same name into one.
TypeScript.ex: interface A { x: number; } interface A { y: number; } // merged

TypeScript.q: What is type alias vs interface difference?
TypeScript.a: Type alias can represent primitives or unions; interface cannot.
TypeScript.ex: type ID = string | number; interface User { id: ID; }

TypeScript.a: Refers to the type of the current class instance.
TypeScript.ex: class Counter { count = 0; inc(): this { this.count++; return this; } }

TypeScript.q: How to define a function type?
TypeScript.a: Using function signature syntax.
TypeScript.ex: let add: (a: number, b: number) => number;

TypeScript.q: What is the difference between 'let', 'const', and 'var'?
TypeScript.a: let/const have block scope; var has function scope.
TypeScript.ex: if(true){ let a=1; var b=2; } console.log(b); // works

TypeScript.a: Provide default types for generics.
TypeScript.ex: function identity<T = string>(value: T): T { return value; }

TypeScript.a: Used for asynchronous operations using promises.
TypeScript.ex: async function fetchData() { const res = await fetch('/api'); }

TypeScript.q: What are the disadvantages of TypeScript?
TypeScript.a: Requires compilation, setup overhead, and may be verbose for small apps.
TypeScript.ex: // must compile before running: tsc index.ts

TypeScript.q: What is the difference between compile-time and run-time type checking?
TypeScript.a: TypeScript checks at compile-time; JavaScript checks at runtime.
TypeScript.ex: let num: number = 'abc'; // compile error

TypeScript.q: What is the 'never' type used for in functions?
TypeScript.a: For functions that never return or throw an error.
TypeScript.ex: function crash(): never { throw new Error('Fail'); }

TypeScript.q: Can TypeScript run directly in the browser?
TypeScript.a: No, it must be compiled into JavaScript first.
TypeScript.ex: // compile using: tsc script.ts

Node.js.q: What is Node.js?
Node.js.a: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine for server-side development.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between Node.js and JavaScript in the browser?
Node.js.a: Node.js runs on the server, browser JS runs on client-side.

Node.js.q: What is EventEmitter in Node.js?
Node.js.a: EventEmitter is a core module that facilitates event-driven programming with emitters and listeners.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between process.nextTick() and setImmediate()?
Node.js.a: nextTick runs before the next event loop iteration, setImmediate runs on the next iteration.

Node.js.q: What is middleware in Express.js?
Node.js.a: Functions executed during the request-response cycle, which can modify request/response or call next middleware.

Node.js.q: What is npm?
Node.js.a: Node Package Manager for installing and managing Node.js packages.

Node.js.q: What is a buffer in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Global object to handle binary data streams.

Node.js.q: What are streams in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Objects used to read or write data piece by piece instead of loading it all at once.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between readable and writable streams?
Node.js.a: Readable streams allow reading data, writable streams allow writing data.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous APIs in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Synchronous APIs block execution, asynchronous APIs do not.

Node.js.q: What is callback hell?
Node.js.a: Nested callbacks making code hard to read and maintain.

Node.js.q: What is a promise in Node.js?
Node.js.a: An object representing eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation.

Node.js.q: What is async/await in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Syntactic sugar over promises to write asynchronous code in a synchronous style.

Node.js.q: What is cluster module in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Allows running multiple Node.js processes to utilize multi-core CPUs.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between fork() and spawn() in Node.js?
Node.js.a: spawn launches a new process, fork launches a new Node.js instance with IPC support.

Node.js.q: What is CORS in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing, a mechanism to allow restricted resources on a web page to be requested from another domain.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between require and import?
Node.js.a: require is CommonJS syntax, import is ES6 module syntax.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between __dirname and process.cwd()?
Node.js.a: __dirname gives the directory of the current module, process.cwd() gives the current working directory.

Node.js.q: What are global objects in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Objects accessible anywhere without requiring modules, e.g., global, process, Buffer.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between module.exports and exports?
Node.js.a: module.exports is the actual exported object, exports is a reference to module.exports.

Node.js.q: What is event loop in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Handles non-blocking I/O by processing callbacks from queues and phases.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between setImmediate and setTimeout in Node.js?
Node.js.a: setImmediate executes after I/O events, setTimeout executes after specified delay.

Node.js.q: What is process object in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Provides information about the current Node.js process and methods to interact with it.

Node.js.q: What is process.env in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Object containing user environment variables.

Node.js.q: What is REPL in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Read-Eval-Print Loop, an interactive shell for running Node.js code.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between child_process.spawn and exec?
Node.js.a: spawn returns streams, exec buffers output and has callback when complete.

Node.js.q: What is a global module in Node.js?
Node.js.a: A module installed globally to be used across projects using -g flag.

Node.js.q: What is local module in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Modules installed in project node_modules directory.

Node.js.q: What is package.json?
Node.js.a: Metadata file for Node.js project containing dependencies and scripts.

Node.js.q: What is semantic versioning in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Versioning convention using MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH to indicate backward compatibility.

Node.js.q: What is error-first callback?
Node.js.a: Callback pattern where the first argument is an error, and second is result.

Node.js.q: What is process.nextTick()?
Node.js.a: Schedules a callback to be invoked in the next iteration of the event loop, before other I/O events.

Node.js.q: What is domain module in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Deprecated module for handling multiple different I/O operations as a single group.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between synchronous require() and asynchronous import()?
Node.js.a: require() is blocking, import() returns a promise and is non-blocking.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between readable.pipe() and readable.on('data')?
Node.js.a: pipe streams data automatically to writable, 'data' requires manual handling.

Node.js.q: What is the purpose of Node.js crypto module?
Node.js.a: Provides cryptographic functionality like hashing, encryption, and signing.

Node.js.q: What is process.exit()?
Node.js.a: Terminates the Node.js process with optional exit code.

Node.js.q: What is uncaughtException event?
Node.js.a: Event emitted when an exception bubbles all the way back to the event loop.

Node.js.q: What is require.cache?
Node.js.a: Object storing cached modules to prevent reloading.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous file I/O?
Node.js.a: Synchronous blocks execution until operation finishes, asynchronous uses callbacks.

Node.js.q: What is the purpose of the path module in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Provides utilities for working with file and directory paths.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between process.argv and process.env?
Node.js.a: argv contains command-line arguments, env contains environment variables.

Node.js.q: What is a readable stream in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Stream from which data can be read sequentially.

Node.js.q: What is a writable stream in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Stream to which data can be written sequentially.

Node.js.q: What is Duplex stream in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Stream that is both readable and writable.

Node.js.q: What is Transform stream in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Duplex stream that can modify the data as it is read or written.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between npm install and npm install --save?
Node.js.a: --save adds the package to dependencies in package.json.

Node.js.q: What is Node.js REPL command '.help'?
Node.js.a: Displays help commands in the interactive Node.js shell.

Node.js.q: What is the purpose of util.promisify?
Node.js.a: Converts callback-based functions to return promises.

Node.js.q: What is the difference between HTTP and HTTPS module in Node.js?
Node.js.a: HTTPS module provides encrypted communication using TLS/SSL, HTTP is unencrypted.

Node.js.q: What is the purpose of os module in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Provides operating system-related utility methods and properties.

Node.js.q: What is cluster.fork() in Node.js?
Node.js.a: Creates a new worker process to share server load in multi-core systems.

React.js.q: What is React.js?
React.js.a: React.js is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces, developed by Facebook.

React.js.q: What are components in React?
React.js.a: Components are reusable pieces of UI in React, either class-based or functional.

React.js.q: What is the difference between state and props?
React.js.a: State is internal to a component and can change, props are inputs passed from parent and are read-only.

React.js.q: What are React hooks?
React.js.a: Functions like useState and useEffect that let you use state and lifecycle features in functional components.

React.js.q: What is JSX?
React.js.a: JSX is a syntax extension for JavaScript that allows writing HTML-like code inside JavaScript.

React.js.q: What is virtual DOM?
React.js.a: A lightweight copy of the real DOM for efficient updates in React.

React.js.q: What is the difference between class and functional components?
React.js.a: Class components have lifecycle methods and state, functional components use hooks for state and side effects.

React.js.q: What is the useEffect hook?
React.js.a: useEffect allows performing side effects in functional components, like fetching data or manipulating DOM.

React.js.q: What is the useState hook?
React.js.a: useState allows adding state to functional components.

React.js.q: What is the difference between controlled and uncontrolled components?
React.js.a: Controlled components have their value managed by React state, uncontrolled components store value in DOM.

React.js.q: What is the purpose of keys in React lists?
React.js.a: Keys help React identify which items have changed, are added, or removed, improving performance.

React.js.q: What is the difference between React Router and traditional routing?
React.js.a: React Router allows client-side routing without page reloads, traditional routing reloads pages from server.

React.js.q: What is context API in React?
React.js.a: Context API allows passing data through the component tree without prop drilling.

React.js.q: What is the difference between useMemo and useCallback?
React.js.a: useMemo memoizes a value, useCallback memoizes a function.

React.js.q: What is the purpose of React.Fragment?
React.js.a: Fragments let you group multiple elements without adding extra nodes to the DOM.

React.js.q: What is the difference between componentDidMount and useEffect?
React.js.a: componentDidMount runs once after mounting in class components, useEffect can run on mount, update, or unmount in functional components.

React.js.q: What are higher-order components (HOC)?
React.js.a: HOCs are functions that take a component and return a new enhanced component.

React.js.q: What is the difference between pure component and regular component?
React.js.a: PureComponent implements shallow comparison for props and state to prevent unnecessary re-renders.

React.js.q: What is reconciliation in React?
React.js.a: Process of comparing new virtual DOM with old virtual DOM to efficiently update the real DOM.

React.js.q: What is lazy loading in React?
React.js.a: Technique to load components or modules only when needed to improve performance.

React.js.q: What is suspense in React?
React.js.a: Suspense allows waiting for lazy-loaded components or data fetching before rendering fallback content.

React.js.q: What is the difference between stateful and stateless components?
React.js.a: Stateful components have internal state, stateless components rely entirely on props.

React.js.q: What is prop drilling and how to avoid it?
React.js.a: Prop drilling is passing props through multiple layers; avoided using Context API or state management libraries.

React.js.q: What is the difference between React and Angular?
React.js.a: React is a library focusing on UI, Angular is a full-fledged framework with more features.

React.js.q: What is the difference between React and Vue?
React.js.a: React uses JSX and a virtual DOM; Vue uses template syntax and provides an integrated ecosystem.

React.js.q: What is the difference between useRef and createRef?
React.js.a: useRef is used in functional components, createRef is used in class components.

React.js.q: What is synthetic event in React?
React.js.a: Cross-browser wrapper around native events to provide consistent behavior.

React.js.q: What is the difference between React 16 and 17?
React.js.a: React 17 focuses on gradual upgrades and improved event delegation, no new features.

React.js.q: What is the difference between React 17 and 18?
React.js.a: React 18 introduces concurrent rendering and automatic batching of updates.

React.js.q: What is concurrent mode in React 18?
React.js.a: Concurrent mode allows React to prepare multiple versions of UI without blocking the main thread.

React.js.q: What is the difference between default and named exports?
React.js.a: Default export allows a single export per file, named exports allow multiple exports.

React.js.q: What is error boundary in React?
React.js.a: Component that catches JavaScript errors anywhere in its child component tree and displays fallback UI.

React.js.q: What is server-side rendering (SSR) in React?
React.js.a: Rendering React components on the server to send fully rendered HTML to clients.

React.js.q: What is the difference between SSR and CSR?
React.js.a: SSR renders pages on server, CSR renders pages on client browser.

React.js.q: What is the difference between ReactDOM.render and createRoot?
React.js.a: createRoot is used in React 18 for concurrent features, ReactDOM.render is legacy.

React.js.q: What is hydration in React?
React.js.a: Hydration is attaching event listeners to server-rendered HTML for client-side interactivity.

React.js.q: What is memoization in React?
React.js.a: Optimization technique to cache computed values or components to prevent unnecessary re-renders.

React.js.q: What is the difference between state lifting and context?
React.js.a: Lifting state shares data between parent and child, context allows passing data deeper without prop drilling.

React.js.q: What is reconciliation and diffing algorithm?
React.js.a: Algorithm to compare new virtual DOM with previous one to update only changed parts.

React.js.q: What is the difference between key and ref in React?
React.js.a: Key helps React track list items for rendering, ref gives access to DOM or component instance.

React.js.q: What is the difference between controlled and uncontrolled inputs?
React.js.a: Controlled inputs are bound to state, uncontrolled inputs use DOM for value.

React.js.q: What is Portals in React?
React.js.a: Portals allow rendering children into a DOM node outside the parent hierarchy.

React.js.q: What is the difference between useLayoutEffect and useEffect?
React.js.a: useLayoutEffect fires synchronously after DOM mutations, useEffect fires asynchronously after render.

React.js.q: What is the difference between React.memo and PureComponent?
React.js.a: React.memo is HOC for functional components, PureComponent is for class components.

React.js.q: What is the difference between render props and HOC?
React.js.a: Render props pass a function as a prop, HOC wraps a component and returns enhanced component.

React.js.q: What is reconciliation strategy for lists?
React.js.a: Use unique keys to help React efficiently update list items.

React.js.q: What is the difference between useReducer and useState?
React.js.a: useReducer is preferred for complex state logic, useState for simple state management.

React.js.q: What is React Profiler?
React.js.a: Tool to measure performance of React components and detect bottlenecks.

React.js.q: What is hydration mismatch warning?
React.js.a: Occurs when server-rendered HTML doesn't match client-side rendering.

React.js.q: What is the difference between lazy loading components and code splitting?
React.js.a: Lazy loading is for individual components, code splitting divides app into multiple bundles.

React.js.q: What is the purpose of forwardRef?
React.js.a: Allows passing ref from parent to child component to access DOM or instance.

React.js.q: What is SuspenseList in React 18?
React.js.a: Component that coordinates the order in which multiple Suspense components show their content.

React.js.q: What is the difference between batch updates and individual updates?
React.js.a: Batch updates combine multiple state changes to reduce re-renders, individual updates render immediately.

React.js.q: What is the purpose of useImperativeHandle?
React.js.a: Customizes the instance value exposed to parent when using ref.

React.js.q: What is the difference between controlled component and uncontrolled component?
React.js.a: Controlled component value is managed by React state, uncontrolled uses DOM for state.

Vue.js.q: What is Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Vue.js is a progressive JavaScript framework for building user interfaces.

Vue.js.q: What is Vuex?
Vue.js.a: Vuex is a state management library for Vue.js applications.

Vue.js.q: Difference between v-if and v-show?
Vue.js.a: v-if conditionally renders elements, v-show toggles visibility using CSS.

Vue.js.q: What is a directive in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Special attributes in templates that provide reactive behavior, e.g., v-bind, v-model.

Vue.js.q: What is a component in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Reusable Vue instance with template, script, and style.

Vue.js.q: What are lifecycle hooks in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Functions called at specific stages of a component's lifecycle, e.g., created, mounted.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between computed properties and methods?
Vue.js.a: Computed properties are cached based on dependencies, methods are not.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between props and data?
Vue.js.a: Props are passed from parent to child components, data is local to the component.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between watchers and computed properties?
Vue.js.a: Watchers observe data changes and execute code, computed properties return values based on dependencies.

Vue.js.q: What is v-bind in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Directive to bind attributes or props to expressions.

Vue.js.q: What is v-model in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Two-way binding directive between input fields and data.

Vue.js.q: What is v-on in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Directive to attach event listeners to elements.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between Vue 2 and Vue 3?
Vue.js.a: Vue 3 uses Composition API, better performance, smaller bundle size, and Proxy-based reactivity.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between global and local components?
Vue.js.a: Global components can be used anywhere, local components are registered inside a component.

Vue.js.q: What is a mixin in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Reusable piece of code that can be included in multiple components.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between key and ref?
Vue.js.a: key is used to track nodes for re-rendering, ref gives direct access to DOM or component instance.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between Vue Router and Vuex?
Vue.js.a: Vue Router handles navigation between pages, Vuex handles state management.

Vue.js.q: What is scoped CSS in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: CSS that applies only to the current component, not globally.

Vue.js.q: What is a dynamic component in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: A component that can switch between different child components dynamically using <component> tag.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between $emit and v-model?
Vue.js.a: $emit is used to send events from child to parent, v-model is two-way binding.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between Vue.js and React?
Vue.js.a: Vue is template-based with options API, React is JSX and component-based with hooks.

Vue.js.q: What is reactivity in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: System that tracks data changes and automatically updates the DOM.

Vue.js.q: What is the purpose of provide/inject in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Allow passing data from parent to deeply nested child components without prop drilling.

Vue.js.q: What is a single-file component (SFC)?
Vue.js.a: A component containing template, script, and style in a single .vue file.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between v-pre and v-once?
Vue.js.a: v-pre skips compilation, v-once renders element only once and caches it.

Vue.js.q: What is a slot in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Placeholder for content passed from parent to child component.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between default slot and named slot?
Vue.js.a: Default slot has no name, named slot allows multiple slots with unique names.

Vue.js.q: What is async component in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Component that is loaded lazily to reduce initial bundle size.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between shallowMount and mount in Vue Test Utils?
Vue.js.a: shallowMount mounts component without rendering child components, mount renders everything.

Vue.js.q: What is watchEffect in Vue 3?
Vue.js.a: Reactive effect that automatically tracks dependencies and re-runs when they change.

Vue.js.q: What is Composition API?
Vue.js.a: Vue 3 API using setup() function to organize code by logic rather than options.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between reactive and ref?
Vue.js.a: reactive creates reactive objects, ref creates reactive primitive values.

Vue.js.q: What is teleport in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Allows rendering a component in a different part of the DOM.

Vue.js.q: What is a directive hook?
Vue.js.a: Lifecycle hooks of a custom directive, e.g., bind, inserted, update, unbind.

Vue.js.q: What is keep-alive in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Component wrapper to cache inactive components to preserve state.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between v-html and mustache syntax?
Vue.js.a: v-html renders raw HTML, mustache escapes HTML and renders text.

Vue.js.q: What is the purpose of nextTick?
Vue.js.a: Defers the callback until after the DOM has been updated.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between shallowRef and ref in Vue 3?
Vue.js.a: shallowRef makes top-level object reactive, nested objects are not reactive.

Vue.js.q: What is a plugin in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Reusable library that adds global-level functionality to Vue applications.

Vue.js.q: What is dynamic props in Vue.js?
Vue.js.a: Props bound to expressions that can change dynamically.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between v-for and v-if on the same element?
Vue.js.a: v-for has higher priority than v-if; v-if runs after v-for loop evaluation.

Vue.js.q: What is suspense in Vue 3?
Vue.js.a: Component to handle async component loading with fallback content.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between watch and watchEffect?
Vue.js.a: watch tracks specific sources, watchEffect tracks reactive dependencies automatically.

Vue.js.q: What is the purpose of provide/inject vs props?
Vue.js.a: provide/inject avoids prop drilling for deeply nested components.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between a computed setter and watcher?
Vue.js.a: Computed setter allows modifying reactive value, watcher reacts to changes to perform side effects.

Vue.js.q: What is a mixin vs composition API?
Vue.js.a: Mixin is a reusable object with options, composition API organizes logic functionally.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between Vue 3 createApp and Vue 2 new Vue?
Vue.js.a: createApp creates a new app instance with methods like mount, Vue 2 uses constructor new Vue().

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between functional component and stateful component?
Vue.js.a: Functional component is stateless, lightweight, and faster; stateful component maintains internal state.

Vue.js.q: What is the purpose of app.config.globalProperties?
Vue.js.a: Allows adding global properties/methods to be accessible in all components.

Vue.js.q: What is the difference between watch array and watch deep object?
Vue.js.a: Deep option allows watching nested object changes, array watch tracks array changes.

Vue.js.q: What is the purpose of v-cloak?
Vue.js.a: Directive to hide uncompiled template until Vue instance is mounted.

HTML.q: What is HTML?
HTML.a: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard language for creating web pages.

HTML.q: What are semantic HTML tags?
HTML.a: Tags like <header>, <footer>, <article>, <section> that give meaning to content.

HTML.q: Difference between inline and block elements?
HTML.a: Block elements take full width and start on a new line; inline elements take only necessary width and stay in line.

HTML.q: What is the difference between HTML5 and HTML4?
HTML.a: HTML5 introduced semantic elements, audio/video support, canvas, local storage, and new APIs.

HTML.q: What are meta tags?
HTML.a: Tags in <head> that provide metadata about the document, like description, keywords, and viewport.

HTML.q: What is the difference between id and class?
HTML.a: id is unique for one element, class can be used for multiple elements.

HTML.q: What is the purpose of the alt attribute in images?
HTML.a: Provides alternative text for images when they cannot be displayed or for accessibility.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <div> and <span>?
HTML.a: <div> is block-level, <span> is inline-level.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <section> and <article>?
HTML.a: <section> is a thematic grouping, <article> is self-contained content that can be distributed independently.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <strong> and <b>?
HTML.a: <strong> indicates importance, <b> is purely stylistic bold text.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <em> and <i>?
HTML.a: <em> indicates emphasis, <i> is purely stylistic italic text.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <ul>, <ol>, and <dl>?
HTML.a: <ul> is unordered list, <ol> is ordered list, <dl> is definition list.

HTML.q: What is the purpose of the <form> tag?
HTML.a: Used to collect user input and submit data to a server.

HTML.q: What is the difference between GET and POST methods in forms?
HTML.a: GET appends data in URL, POST sends data in the request body.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <input type='text'> and <textarea>?
HTML.a: <input> is single-line text input, <textarea> is multi-line input.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <button> and <input type='submit'>?
HTML.a: <button> can have content and styles, input type='submit' is limited and triggers form submission.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <link> and <style>?
HTML.a: <link> links external CSS, <style> contains internal CSS in the HTML document.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <script src> and inline <script>?
HTML.a: <script src> loads external JavaScript, inline <script> contains JS inside the HTML.

HTML.q: What are data-* attributes?
HTML.a: Custom attributes that store data private to the page or application.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <iframe> and <embed>?
HTML.a: <iframe> embeds another HTML document, <embed> embeds multimedia content like PDF or video.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <header> and <nav>?
HTML.a: <header> contains introductory content, <nav> contains navigation links.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <footer> and <address>?
HTML.a: <footer> is general footer of a page, <address> provides contact information.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <bdo> and <span>?
HTML.a: <bdo> overrides text direction, <span> is general inline container.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <cite> and <q>?
HTML.a: <cite> represents a reference to a work, <q> represents a short inline quotation.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <figure> and <figcaption>?
HTML.a: <figure> is a container for media, <figcaption> provides caption for <figure> content.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <small> and <sub>/<sup>?
HTML.a: <small> reduces font size, <sub>/<sup> formats text as subscript or superscript.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <main> and <section>?
HTML.a: <main> indicates main content, <section> is a thematic grouping of content.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <mark> and <span>?
HTML.a: <mark> highlights text semantically, <span> is generic inline container.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <del> and <s>?
HTML.a: <del> indicates deleted text, <s> is purely stylistic strike-through.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <ins> and <u>?
HTML.a: <ins> indicates inserted text, <u> is purely stylistic underline.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <time> and <date>?
HTML.a: <time> represents time or date, <date> is obsolete in HTML5.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <audio> and <video>?
HTML.a: <audio> plays sound, <video> plays video with optional sound.

HTML.q: What is the difference between preload, autoplay, and controls attributes in media?
HTML.a: preload loads media in advance, autoplay plays automatically, controls show playback UI.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <canvas> and <svg>?
HTML.a: <canvas> is bitmap-based drawing, <svg> is vector-based graphics.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <meta charset> and <meta name='viewport'>?
HTML.a: charset defines character encoding, viewport defines layout on different devices.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <base> and <link>?
HTML.a: <base> sets default URL for relative links, <link> references external resources.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <object> and <embed>?
HTML.a: <object> can contain fallback content, <embed> is self-contained.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <details> and <summary>?
HTML.a: <details> creates collapsible content, <summary> provides a title for it.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <dl>, <dt>, and <dd>?
HTML.a: <dl> is a definition list, <dt> is term, <dd> is definition.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <abbr> and <acronym>?
HTML.a: <abbr> defines abbreviation, <acronym> is obsolete in HTML5.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <meta http-equiv> and <meta name>?
HTML.a: http-equiv simulates HTTP headers, name defines metadata properties.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <progress> and <meter>?
HTML.a: <progress> shows task completion, <meter> shows a scalar measurement within range.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <template> and <slot>?
HTML.a: <template> defines inert HTML for reuse, <slot> is placeholder for child content in components.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <link rel='stylesheet'> and <style>?
HTML.a: link loads external CSS, style contains inline CSS.

HTML.q: What is the difference between HTML attribute and property?
HTML.a: Attribute is defined in markup, property is DOM object representation of the attribute.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <nav> and <menu>?
HTML.a: <nav> is for navigation links, <menu> is for context menus or list of commands.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <blockquote> and <q>?
HTML.a: <blockquote> for block quotes, <q> for inline quotes.

HTML.q: What is the difference between HTML and XHTML?
HTML.a: XHTML is stricter XML-based markup, HTML is less strict and forgiving.

HTML.q: What is the difference between <form> action='' and method='get/post'?
HTML.a: action specifies URL for form submission, method specifies HTTP request type.

CSS.q: What is CSS?
CSS.a: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is used to style HTML elements on a web page.

CSS.q: What is SCSS?
CSS.a: SCSS is a syntax of SASS, a CSS preprocessor that adds features like variables, nesting, and mixins.

CSS.q: Difference between relative, absolute, fixed, and sticky positioning?
CSS.a: Relative: relative to itself; Absolute: relative to nearest positioned ancestor; Fixed: relative to viewport; Sticky: toggles between relative and fixed based on scroll.

CSS.q: What is the difference between inline, inline-block, and block elements?
CSS.a: Inline: flows with text, width/height ignored; Inline-block: flows inline but allows width/height; Block: starts on new line, takes full width.

CSS.q: What is the difference between ID and class selectors?
CSS.a: ID is unique, prefixed with #; class can be reused, prefixed with .

CSS.q: What is the difference between relative and absolute units in CSS?
CSS.a: Relative units (%) depend on parent, viewport; Absolute units (px, cm) are fixed.

CSS.q: What is the difference between em, rem, and px?
CSS.a: em is relative to parent font-size, rem is relative to root font-size, px is fixed pixels.

CSS.q: What is the difference between inline style and external stylesheet?
CSS.a: Inline styles are inside HTML elements; external stylesheets are separate CSS files linked via <link>.

CSS.q: What is the difference between relative, absolute, fixed, and sticky position?
CSS.a: Same as above; relative: moves relative to self, absolute: relative to nearest positioned ancestor, fixed: viewport, sticky: scroll-based toggle.

CSS.q: What is the difference between float and flex?
CSS.a: Float is for wrapping text/images; flex is a modern layout system for arranging items in a container.

CSS.q: What is the difference between inline styles and classes?
CSS.a: Inline styles apply only to one element; classes can style multiple elements.

CSS.q: What is the difference between z-index and stacking context?
CSS.a: z-index sets element order in stacking context; stacking context is created by positioned elements and controls z-index behavior.

CSS.q: What is the difference between relative and absolute positioning?
CSS.a: Relative moves element relative to itself; absolute positions element relative to nearest positioned ancestor.

CSS.q: What is the difference between CSS Grid and Flexbox?
CSS.a: Grid is for two-dimensional layouts (rows and columns); Flexbox is for one-dimensional layouts (row or column).

CSS.q: What is the difference between visibility:hidden and display:none?
CSS.a: visibility:hidden hides element but occupies space; display:none removes element from layout.

CSS.q: What is the difference between min-width, max-width, and width?
CSS.a: width sets fixed size, min-width sets minimum size, max-width sets maximum size.

CSS.q: What is the difference between relative and absolute length units?
CSS.a: Relative units depend on context (%, em, rem), absolute units are fixed (px, cm).

CSS.q: What is the difference between position:relative and float?
CSS.a: Relative moves element in normal flow; float removes element partially from normal flow for wrapping.

CSS.q: What is the difference between pseudo-class and pseudo-element?
CSS.a: Pseudo-class (:hover) selects element state; pseudo-element (::before) selects part of element content.

CSS.q: What is the difference between inline, block, and inline-block?
CSS.a: Block: new line, full width; Inline: flows inline; Inline-block: inline but accepts width/height.

CSS.q: What is the difference between rem and em?
CSS.a: rem is relative to root font-size, em is relative to parent font-size.

CSS.q: What is the difference between relative and absolute positioning?
CSS.a: Relative moves element from its normal position; absolute positions element relative to nearest positioned ancestor.

CSS.q: What is the difference between SCSS and SASS?
CSS.a: SCSS uses CSS-like syntax with braces and semicolons; SASS uses indentation-based syntax.

CSS.q: What is the difference between import and @import in SCSS?
CSS.a: Import is modern ES6 style; @import in SCSS imports another SCSS file for compilation.

CSS.q: What are mixins in SCSS?
CSS.a: Reusable blocks of code that can be included in other selectors with parameters.

CSS.q: What are variables in SCSS?
CSS.a: Variables store values like colors, fonts, or sizes for reuse across stylesheets.

CSS.q: What is the difference between nesting and BEM?
CSS.a: Nesting organizes selectors hierarchically; BEM is a naming convention for readability and maintainability.

CSS.q: What is the difference between extend and mixin in SCSS?
CSS.a: Extend shares styles via inheritance; mixin includes reusable block of code with optional parameters.

CSS.q: What is the difference between pseudo-class and pseudo-element?
CSS.a: Pseudo-class (:hover) targets state; pseudo-element (::before) targets part of element.

CSS.q: What is the difference between transition and animation?
CSS.a: Transition handles state changes over time; animation defines multiple keyframes for complex animations.

CSS.q: What is the difference between keyframes and transitions?
CSS.a: Keyframes define multiple stages for animations; transitions define change from one state to another.

CSS.q: What is the difference between relative, fixed, sticky, and absolute?
CSS.a: Relative: relative to itself; absolute: relative to positioned ancestor; fixed: viewport; sticky: toggles relative/fixed.

CSS.q: What is the difference between opacity and visibility?
CSS.a: Opacity makes element semi-transparent but still interactive; visibility:hidden hides element but occupies space.

CSS.q: What is the difference between inline, inline-block, and block?
CSS.a: Inline: flows with text; Inline-block: inline with width/height; Block: new line full-width.

CSS.q: What is the difference between SCSS variables and CSS variables?
CSS.a: SCSS variables are compiled at build time; CSS variables are live in browser and can be updated dynamically.

CSS.q: What is the difference between position sticky and fixed?
CSS.a: Sticky toggles between relative and fixed based on scroll; fixed is always relative to viewport.

CSS.q: What is the difference between absolute and fixed position?
CSS.a: Absolute: relative to nearest positioned ancestor; Fixed: relative to viewport.

CSS.q: What is the difference between flex-start, flex-end, center, space-between, space-around in Flexbox?
CSS.a: Aligns items along main axis: start, end, center, evenly spaced, or spaced around.

CSS.q: What is the difference between align-items and align-content?
CSS.a: align-items aligns items on cross-axis; align-content aligns multiple lines of flex items.

CSS.q: What is the difference between justify-content and align-items?
CSS.a: justify-content aligns items on main axis; align-items aligns items on cross-axis.

CSS.q: What is the difference between grid-template-columns and grid-template-rows?
CSS.a: Defines number and size of columns vs rows in CSS Grid layout.

CSS.q: What is the difference between auto-fill and auto-fit in CSS Grid?
CSS.a: auto-fill fills row/column with as many tracks as possible; auto-fit stretches tracks to fill space.

CSS.q: What is the difference between @mixin and @function in SCSS?
CSS.a: Mixin inserts reusable styles; function returns a value to use in styles.

CSS.q: What is the difference between SCSS partial and normal SCSS file?
CSS.a: Partial files start with _ and are not compiled separately; normal SCSS files are compiled to CSS.

CSS.q: What is the difference between z-index and stacking context?
CSS.a: z-index sets order within stacking context; stacking context determines hierarchy of elements.

CSS.q: What is the difference between CSS variables and SCSS variables?
CSS.a: CSS variables are runtime, dynamic; SCSS variables are compile-time, static.

CSS.q: What is the difference between relative and absolute units?
CSS.a: Relative units depend on context (%/em/rem), absolute units are fixed (px/cm/in).

CSS.q: What is the difference between rem and em units?
CSS.a: rem is relative to root font-size, em is relative to parent font-size.

CSS.q: What is the difference between CSS Grid and Flexbox?
CSS.a: Grid is two-dimensional layout (rows+columns), Flexbox is one-dimensional layout (row or column).

CSS.q: What is the difference between transition and animation?
CSS.a: Transition is triggered by state change; animation is defined using keyframes for multiple steps.

NestJS.q: What is NestJS?
NestJS.a: NestJS is a progressive Node.js framework for building efficient, reliable, and scalable server-side applications.

NestJS.q: What is a module in NestJS?
NestJS.a: A module is a class annotated with @Module decorator that organizes the application structure.

NestJS.q: What are controllers in NestJS?
NestJS.a: Controllers handle incoming HTTP requests and return responses to the client.

NestJS.q: What are providers in NestJS?
NestJS.a: Providers are services or classes that can be injected using dependency injection.

NestJS.q: What is dependency injection in NestJS?
NestJS.a: A design pattern that allows a class to receive dependencies from external sources rather than creating them.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @Injectable() and @Controller()?
NestJS.a: @Injectable() marks a class as a provider; @Controller() marks a class as a controller handling routes.

NestJS.q: What is middleware in NestJS?
NestJS.a: Functions that are executed before the route handler, useful for logging, authentication, etc.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between middleware and interceptor?
NestJS.a: Middleware runs before route handlers; interceptors can manipulate requests/responses and run before or after handlers.

NestJS.q: What is an interceptor in NestJS?
NestJS.a: Class annotated with @Injectable() that implements NestInterceptor to bind extra logic to request/response lifecycle.

NestJS.q: What is a pipe in NestJS?
NestJS.a: A class annotated with @Injectable() that implements transformation and validation logic for incoming data.

NestJS.q: What is a guard in NestJS?
NestJS.a: A class implementing CanActivate interface that determines whether a request is allowed to proceed.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @Get(), @Post(), @Put(), @Delete() decorators?
NestJS.a: They map HTTP methods GET, POST, PUT, DELETE to controller route handlers.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous providers?
NestJS.a: Synchronous providers return immediately; asynchronous providers use async/await or Promises.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between forRoot() and forFeature() in NestJS modules?
NestJS.a: forRoot() configures global module providers; forFeature() registers module-specific providers.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between forwardRef() and normal imports?
NestJS.a: forwardRef() resolves circular dependencies between modules or providers.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @Body(), @Param(), and @Query()?
NestJS.a: @Body() gets data from request body, @Param() gets route parameters, @Query() gets query parameters.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between class-validator and class-transformer?
NestJS.a: class-validator validates object properties; class-transformer transforms plain objects to class instances.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous pipes?
NestJS.a: Synchronous pipes execute instantly; asynchronous pipes return Promises or Observables.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between HTTP exception and standard exception?
NestJS.a: HTTP exception sends formatted HTTP error responses; standard exception is general JavaScript error.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @Req() and @Request()?
NestJS.a: Both inject request object; @Req() is alias commonly used for readability.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @Res() and return statement?
NestJS.a: @Res() gives full control over response object; returning a value lets Nest handle response automatically.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous guards?
NestJS.a: Synchronous guards return boolean; asynchronous guards return Promise<boolean> or Observable<boolean>.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between interceptors and middleware?
NestJS.a: Interceptors can modify responses and exceptions; middleware only runs before route handlers.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between global and scoped providers?
NestJS.a: Global providers are available app-wide; scoped providers are limited to a specific request or module.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between singleton and transient providers?
NestJS.a: Singleton: one instance per app; transient: new instance per injection.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous module initialization?
NestJS.a: Synchronous initialization runs immediately; asynchronous allows async configuration before module is ready.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @Inject() and constructor injection?
NestJS.a: @Inject() explicitly specifies a provider token; constructor injection lets Nest resolve dependencies automatically.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between Monolithic and Microservice architecture in NestJS?
NestJS.a: Monolithic runs as a single app; microservices run as multiple independent services communicating over network.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between TCP, gRPC, and RabbitMQ in NestJS?
NestJS.a: TCP and gRPC are transport layers for microservices; RabbitMQ is a message broker for async messaging.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @Injectable() and @Global()?
NestJS.a: @Injectable() registers provider; @Global() makes module providers available globally without import.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous event listeners?
NestJS.a: Synchronous listeners execute immediately; asynchronous listeners execute in event loop without blocking.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @UseGuards() and app.useGlobalGuards()?
NestJS.a: UseGuards applies guards at controller/route level; useGlobalGuards applies guards globally to all routes.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @UseInterceptors() and app.useGlobalInterceptors()?
NestJS.a: UseInterceptors applies interceptors at route/controller; useGlobalInterceptors applies globally.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @Catch() and try/catch?
NestJS.a: @Catch() handles exceptions centrally via Exception Filters; try/catch handles locally.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between Exception Filters and Pipes?
NestJS.a: Filters handle errors; pipes handle validation and transformation.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @InjectRepository() and TypeORM repository?
NestJS.a: InjectRepository injects repository for a specific entity; TypeORM repository is general repository instance.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between NestJS and Express?
NestJS.a: NestJS is a structured framework built on top of Express with dependency injection, modules, and decorators.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @UsePipes() and app.useGlobalPipes()?
NestJS.a: UsePipes applies to controller/route; useGlobalPipes applies to all requests globally.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between async/await and Observables in NestJS?
NestJS.a: async/await handles Promises; Observables provide streams of data with reactive operators.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @MessagePattern() and @EventPattern()?
NestJS.a: MessagePattern handles request-response messages; EventPattern handles one-way event messages.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between NestJS CLI and manual setup?
NestJS.a: CLI scaffolds project structure quickly; manual setup requires configuring modules and dependencies manually.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between forwardRef() and circular dependencies?
NestJS.a: forwardRef() resolves circular dependencies; circular dependencies occur when two providers import each other.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous microservices?
NestJS.a: Synchronous microservices wait for response; asynchronous communicate via events/messages.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between request-scoped and singleton-scoped providers?
NestJS.a: Request-scoped creates new instance per request; singleton-scoped creates one instance for the app lifetime.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between HTTPModule and Axios in NestJS?
NestJS.a: HTTPModule wraps Axios for dependency injection; Axios can be used standalone for HTTP requests.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between NestJS Lifecycle hooks and Angular lifecycle hooks?
NestJS.a: Similar hooks for initialization and destruction; Angular is client-side, NestJS is server-side.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between NestFactory.create() and NestFactory.createMicroservice()?
NestJS.a: create() starts an HTTP server; createMicroservice() starts a microservice transport layer.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between global filters, guards, pipes, and interceptors?
NestJS.a: They apply globally for exceptions, authorization, validation, and request/response manipulation respectively.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between NestJS WebSockets and microservice transport?
NestJS.a: WebSockets provide real-time bidirectional communication; microservice transport is for distributed service communication.

NestJS.q: What is the difference between @SetMetadata() and Reflector in NestJS?
NestJS.a: @SetMetadata sets custom metadata on controllers/routes; Reflector retrieves metadata at runtime.
